body: Nope, you are checking that url works but i think current tests already do that, what we are missing is that the rendered html contains the proper links to other pages and such.

Let me know what you think!

Nice! a dbapi and sqlalchemy support are great assets for the Apache Drill community. Make sure to share that if you haven't already!

You may want to debug around here, see if columns are lined up when calling:
`pd.DataFrame(data, columns=column_names)`
https://github.com/airbnb/superset/blob/master/superset/sql_lab.py#L126
This looks like an easy patch, care to open a pull request?
This broke the build, reverting. We can bring it back when fixed

Salut Maxime, 
I definitely intend to share it once it is in a presentable and more stable state. John Omernik started working on this, but his dialect used Drillâ€™s ODBC interface.  Iâ€™ve had a lot of issues getting Drill to work with ODBC so I decided to use pydrill which uses the RESTful interface and hence no additional drivers to configure.  However, PyDrill isnâ€™t DBAPI compliant, so I first had to build thatâ€¦ This was way more complicated than I first imagined, but Iâ€™m learning a lot so itâ€™s fun. 
Thanks for the tip and Iâ€™ll probably have other questions as I go forward.  
Best,
â€” C

I had a quick look and it actually looks like the screen I saw from firefox which makes me/new user more comfortable that they are doing things right:)

I likes the clarification of slice=query concept which I guessed but not sure until read about it. This slides do help new user to understand what problem superset is about to solve.

One thing I still have puzzle is postgresql URI. I remember I used sqlite3 somehow, considering I have no idea about what superset was at that time.  Does this mean new example data is stored in postgresql? Or it's OK to use postgresql/sqlite3 here provided you modify config.py correspondingly? I do modify that to use sqlite3 since I just want a quick try when I have no postgresql installed.

I'd love to, but I spent quite some time and didn't really figured out the whole path from the header definition to the react rendering.
 
Maybe @ascott can chime in and give me a hint?

Yes, I can understand how the use of PostgreSQL for the example is confusing. I believe the example data that comes pre-loaded with Superset (e.g. the birth name data) is still stored in SQLite. Since part of the goal of the tutorial is to show administrators how to connect to new data sources, I had to use a different database.

Here, I didn't make any changes to any of the Python code - I just formatted a [SQLAlchemy connection URI](http://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/latest/core/engines.html#database-urls) tied to a database I installed on my local machine. 

Since SQLLite is supported by SQLAlchemy, if you've already installed that, you can connect Superset to data there. See the [connection docs for SQLLite](http://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/latest/core/engines.html#sqlite).

It's also clear that we can separate the database connection portion of the tutorial (for administrators) from the exploration / dashboard portion (for normal users). For the exploration section, it might make sense to use the birth name data - since that comes pre-installed - so that users can follow along. I can make that change.

Does that help?

This is awesome! Would love to bring that to replace what is currently here: http://airbnb.io/superset/tutorial.html . The docs are written in rst format which isn't the greatest but is pretty easy to pick up. It's pretty much just a matter of editing the rst files and running the `python setup.py build_sphinx` command from the root of the repo. You can then point you browser to the folder where sphinx puts the static html files. You may have to run `pip install -r dev-reqs.txt` prior to that to install some package dependencies. 

Would love if you or someone else could translate that doc to rst and send PR.

Here's the rst behind the current tutorial:
https://github.com/airbnb/superset/blob/master/docs/tutorial.rst
@mistercrunch awesome, I can definitely submit a PR. Thanks!

I don't feel very strongly about this, but it could live more generically in LabelWithTooltip component as a `labelActions` (couldn't find a better name) props that would expect a `node` and render to the right of the label itself.

That would allow for any field to add elements right to the label.

I'm very familiar with the pyhive package which does the same thing (dbapi + sqlalchemy) for both Hive and Presto. It can be a good resource as you are building something very similar, especially Presto since it has its own REST api as well (Hive is thrift).

https://github.com/dropbox/PyHive
nope, had to kill the queries

@mistercrunch the Sphinx build is working well - getting the tutorial converted to rst without many problems. Thanks for the dev advice.

One question: the current tutorial references images in docs/_static/, e.g.

`.. image:: _static/img/tutorial/db_plus.png`

but the images themselves aren't committed to the repo, which makes sense. When I commit the PR, I'm just wondering how I actually get y'all the new images so that the docs build correctly?
how have you installed superset? What does latest version of superset means to you? Is it 0.15.1 or master? Please use the issue template.
superset@0.15.1 is the current version.

Make sure these boxes are checked before submitting your issue - thank you!

- [ ] I have checked the superset logs for python stacktraces and included it here as text if any
- [ ] I have reproduced the issue with at least the latest released version of superset
- [X] I have checked the issue tracker for the same issue and I haven't found one similar


### Superset version
0.15.1

### Expected results
goto http://localhost:8088/
login

### Actual results
there are missing asset files, page renders without css and files mentioned in the first post to the issue


### Steps to reproduce
on ubuntu install it via

```bash
sudo apt-get install build-essential libssl-dev libffi-dev python-dev python-pip libsasl2-dev libldap2-dev python-numpy

sudo pip install numpy --proxy=$HTTP_PROXY
sudo pip install pandas --proxy=$HTTP_PROXY
sudo pip install cffi --proxy=$HTTP_PROXY
sudo pip install superset --proxy=$HTTP_PROXY

sudo pip install flask-migrate flask-script flask-testing flask-sqlalchemy humanize gunicorn markdown pandas parsedatetime pydruid PyHive python-dateutil requests simplejson six sqlalchemy sqlalchemy-utils sqlparse thrift thrift-sasl werkzeug  --proxy=$HTTP_PROXY --upgrade

```

bring up the server
```bash
# Create an admin user with credentials (admin/admin)
sudo fabmanager create-admin --app superset


# Initialize the database
sudo superset db upgrade

# Load some data to play with
sudo superset load_examples

# Create default roles and permissions
sudo superset init

# Start the web server on port 8088
sudo superset runserver -p 8088
```
I can just use a older release of the codebase 0.15.0 to see if it still has this issue. But most likely, just problem with running behind proxies.

@vera-liu ï¼Œyesï¼Œit work when I updated the file â€œexplore.0.12.0.entry.jsâ€.
Thanks a lot.
@gregroberts any progress on that so far? Would really love to see superset public dashboard view.
@vera-liu , any solution on this issue so far ?

I'm afraid I haven't really made much progress on this, because the only way I can proceed is guesswork. The set of permissions I have on my Public role is as follows:

	[
	    can show on DashboardModelView,
	    can show on DashboardModelViewAsync,
	    can dashboard on Caravel,
	    can list on DashboardModelView,
	    can list on DashboardModelViewAsync,
	    can edit on DashboardModelViewAsync,
	    can welcome on Caravel
      ]

And what happens on the front end for non logged in users is as follows:

    <domain>/caravel/welcome

shows the Dashboard list page, but it's empty. Looking at the network calls made, the page calls:

    <domain>/dashboardmodelviewasync/api/read?_oc_DashboardModelViewAsync=changed_on&_od_DashboardModelViewAsync=desc

As it does for a logged in user, but no result rows are returned. 

If the user is given a url for a dashboard, e.g.

    <domain>/caravel/dashboard/17/

The dashboard loads and works perfectly fine.

If the user tries to access pretty much any other area of the site, e.g.:

    <domain>/slicemodelview/list/

They are redirected to <domain>/login

This is pretty much all I need for now, and I'm not going to continue because I may be unwittingly poking holes where I don't want them. 

I think this issue is really important, as it will allow users to really customise access across ~Caravel~ Superset.

@xrmx, I made changes. I tested that on the table model view page (the page that comes after clicking the + to add a slice), that each table appears and that the show, edit, and delete buttons are there along with all their URLs.

@ama-ableton np, could you please add some debug as requested in https://github.com/airbnb/superset/issues/1900#issuecomment-270713457 ?

As noted in #1929, i get the same error as the first traceback above. Appears that postgres has two different timestamp column types `TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE`, which I get an error with, and `TIMESTAMP WITHOUT TIME ZONE` which works fine with superset.

Here's the arg1 and arg2 passed into the `issubdtype` function mentioned in the stack trace:

`arg1: datetime64[ns, psycopg2.tz.FixedOffsetTimezone(offset=0, name=None)]`
`arg2: <type 'numpy.number'>`

I just tried selecting only the timestamp column, and got a different trace:

```
2017-01-09 18:03:05,800:ERROR:root:izip argument #2 must support iteration
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/user/src/superset/venv/lib/python2.7/site-packages/superset/views.py", line 2500, in sql_json
    data = sql_lab.get_sql_results(query_id, return_results=True)
  File "/Users/user/src/superset/venv/lib/python2.7/site-packages/celery/local.py", line 188, in __call__
    return self._get_current_object()(*a, **kw)
  File "/Users/user/src/superset/venv/lib/python2.7/site-packages/celery/app/task.py", line 420, in __call__
    return self.run(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/Users/user/src/superset/venv/lib/python2.7/site-packages/superset/sql_lab.py", line 170, in get_sql_results
    payload['data'] = cdf.data if cdf else []
  File "/Users/user/src/superset/venv/lib/python2.7/site-packages/superset/dataframe.py", line 31, in data
    return self.__df.to_dict(orient='records')
  File "/Users/user/src/superset/venv/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pandas/util/decorators.py", line 91, in wrapper
    return func(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/Users/user/src/superset/venv/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pandas/core/frame.py", line 857, in to_dict
    for row in self.values]
TypeError: izip argument #2 must support iteration
```
Sure, does that help?
@mistercrunch  - my fault, will check this out.
@mistercrunch  - fixed the build, will merge and monitor master build.

I love this idea and just wanted to add some thoughts.

Is the activity log of usage (e.g. the database, table, slice, user, metrics added, filters, datetime of query, etc.) recorded anywhere today?

If that log exists (of if we start recording it), you could open that up for exploration so that admins could ask abstract questions of the data (Who's the top user? During what time of the day do we see the most query activity against table X? etc.).

I like the notion of a specific viz, and I think it'd be cool to display the most important usage stats in something fixed like the network diagram, but it seems easier to expose the event-level stats in an intuitive way and let admins create their own usage dashboard specific to their environment.

EDIT: I do see these data in the 'main' database, under 'logs', so apologies for suggesting something that's already possible! I'm still trying to think of how to make the experience with querying that data easier (so much of interesting stuff is stored as properties of the 'json' blob, so it's tougher to get at) so that admins can ask arbitrary usage questions in a simple way.
LGTM
I tried it on a few charts and though I couldn't reproduce the double scrollbar before this LGTM

We have a nice `Superset Usage` dashboard at Airbnb where we track usage over time. Weekly active users, daily active user, recent hourly usage, popular viz types, top dashboards over the past 7 days, top slices, number of content creators, ... We should take the time to ship this along with the examples so that people can track adoption ramping up in their environments.

@BardiaAfshin missing static files usually is matter of compiling your own build and and forget to build them. Since it's not your case to rule out a misconfigured proxy just point to 8088 and see if it loads fine.
BTW If you are using sudo to install superset you are doing something wrong, no need to run superset with privileges, expecially if it's proxied.

It take count variable every where, There is nothing to visualize output of sql query..

Superset is a tool, it won't create visualization on its own. You have to fiddle with the visualization type and its options to make something more appealing than the default count. If you follow the documentation and load the examples you'll see more examples.

@mistercrunch that sounds good, I think that should ship as default when you run `superset init`. I think this would be additive to that though. This is more about seeing the connections. For example it's quite hard to find out which dashboards use a particular metric at the moment, so I don't always know if it's safe to remove. That's eventually the use case I want to cover. Thoughts?

@dylburger we do store the logs, but the parts on metrics and columns are currently stored as json rather as individual values. You can see the logs in the `access logs` menu item.

We've started moving UI to react/JS and using single page apps for both explore V2 and SQL Lab. Currently we don't have support for translations on the front end, and have yet to come up with a pattern of getting translated strings from the server to the front end.

looks like a Flask App Builder template issue. i think the fix may be to add the `safe` filter here where the column value is rendered: 
https://github.com/ascott/superset/blob/master/superset/templates/superset/fab_overrides/list_with_checkboxes.html#L69

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/12672469/how-to-render-html-content-with-jinja-using-flask#12673984
PR should be made from a branch created from a fresh master, please.
deleted 3 spam related comments...

We've found other ways of pex-ing for gunicorn to address this problem (gunicorn forking the process while sqlalchemy is not fork-safe), we'll revert most of this PR as soon as the alternative solution is up.

One first step is to wrap all the strings on the frontend with something like `gettext` on the python side, as in `_('Translate this string')`. I heard webpack can help with extracting the strings, then it'd be a matter of feeding that to [python's] babel somehow. An obvious optimization is to only send the translations needed by the user, I'd guess that webpack can create an entry file for each language.

Unfortunately it's not super high priority for us though, so we probably won't drive this and act more as enablers.
Neat! This reusable component is super useful to have!
LGTM after fixing the `return` statement
@mistercrunch sorry to bug, but the tutorial is finished, just want to figure out how to handle the images (see question above) before I push the PR.

Somehow the perm is created and the permission view menu is pointing to the `datasource_access` perm and null view menu.

Steps: create new table and the go to the ipython console:
```
t = db.session.query(models.SqlaTable).filter_by(id=2783).all()[0]
p = sm.find_permission_view_menu('datasource_access', t.get_perm())
p
>>> datasource access on None
```

Looks like if the `None` view_menu or `None` permission exists it will cause sm.find_permission_view_menu to return that permission view menu object rather than None.
```
    def find_permission_view_menu(self, permission_name, view_menu_name):
        """
            Finds and returns a PermissionView by names
        """
        permission = self.find_permission(permission_name)
        view_menu = self.find_view_menu(view_menu_name)
        return self.get_session.query(self.permissionview_model).filter_by(permission=permission, view_menu=view_menu).first()

```
